content:
There are a lot of issues with the E-needs-mcve label that are unactionable because the author provided no reproducible info (no repository/gist/snippet).
The label description says "Call for participation: This issue needs a Minimal Complete and Verifiable Example". Which to my understanding is a label someone can search for and help with.

Could we add a new label that separates no info provided issues from issues that actually need reduction for example?
It's a good idea, I think other open source projects have labels like more info needed. We somewhat use S-waiting-on-author for that purpose, but it might be better to have an explicit label for it.

I have also always interpreted S-waiting-on-authortwofold as per its description ("This is awaiting some action (such as code changes or more information) from the author").

Currently I see 4 open issues labeled with s-waiting-on-author:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+label%3AS-waiting-on-author+is%3Aissue

The rest of the s-waiting-for-author are PRs which I assume have the other meaning :)
Yeah, S-waiting-on-author is not used much for issues, I think because people (including me) often forget that it could be used for the "needs more info" meaning too.
Maybe we should add S-additional-info-needed as a label?
I also feel like we need to close this sort of issue at some point, because otherwise they sit around forever without any way of knowing whether they've been fixed.
S-needs-info-2022 and close them after a year if theres no followup?
Rough for those people filing issues on 2022-12-25 :-)
We could always just filter by one year ago in the GitHub search (created:<2021-01-01). That would avoid the end-of-year problem.
